hints.label: def-fundamental-group
hints.title: Fundamental Group
hints.content:
621: :label: def-fundamental-group
622: 
623: For a pointed topological space $(X, x_0)$, the **fundamental group** $\pi_1(X, x_0)$ is the group of homotopy classes of loops based at $x_0$:
624: 
625: $$
626: \pi_1(X, x_0) := \{\text{loops } \gamma: [0,1] \to X \text{ with } \gamma(0) = \gamma(1) = x_0\} / \sim
627: 
628: $$
629: 
630: where $\gamma_1 \sim \gamma_2$ if $\gamma_1$ can be continuously deformed to $\gamma_2$ (homotopy).
631: 
632: **Group operation**: Concatenation of loops
633: 
634: $$
635: (\gamma_1 \cdot \gamma_2)(t) := \begin{cases}
636: \gamma_1(2t) & 0 \le t \le 1/2 \\
637: \gamma_2(2t - 1) & 1/2 \le t \le 1
638: \end{cases}
639: 
640: $$
641: 
642: **Identity**: Constant loop at $x_0$
hints.raw_directive:
618: The **fundamental group** $\pi_1(X, x_0)$ captures information about loops that cannot be detected by homology alone.

hints.label: thm-hurewicz
hints.title: Hurewicz Theorem (Abelianization)
hints.content:
648: :label: thm-hurewicz
649: 
650: There is a natural homomorphism (Hurewicz map):
651: 
652: $$
653: h: \pi_1(X, x_0) \to H_1(X)
654: 
655: $$
656: 
657: from the fundamental group to the first homology group. This map is **abelianization** — it quotients out the non-abelian structure:
658: 
659: $$
660: H_1(X) \cong \pi_1(X, x_0) / [\pi_1, \pi_1]
661: 
662: $$
663: 
664: where $[\pi_1, \pi_1]$ is the commutator subgroup.
665: 
666: **Consequence**: Homology $H_1$ counts independent loops but forgets their order. Fundamental group $\pi_1$ retains non-commutative information.

hints.label: thm-homotopy-configuration-space
hints.title: Configuration Space Homotopy (Product Space)
hints.content:
674: :label: thm-homotopy-configuration-space
675: 
676: For the Fragile Gas configuration space $\mathcal{X}^N = \mathcal{X} \times \cdots \times \mathcal{X}$ ($N$ copies), the homotopy groups satisfy:
677: 
678: $$
679: \pi_k(\mathcal{X}^N) \cong \prod_{i=1}^N \pi_k(\mathcal{X})
680: 
681: $$
682: 
683: where the right-hand side is the direct product of $N$ copies of $\pi_k(\mathcal{X})$.
684: 
685: **For $k \ge 2$** (higher homotopy groups are abelian), this simplifies to:
686: 
687: $$
688: \pi_k(\mathcal{X}^N) \cong \bigoplus_{i=1}^N \pi_k(\mathcal{X}) \cong \pi_k(\mathcal{X})^N
689: 
690: $$
691: 
692: using the direct sum notation for abelian groups.
693: 
694: **Proof**: This follows from the universal property of the product topology. A map $f: S^k \to \mathcal{X}^N$ is continuous if and only if its component maps $f_i = p_i \circ f: S^k \to \mathcal{X}$ are continuous, where $p_i: \mathcal{X}^N \to \mathcal{X}$ is the projection onto the $i$-th factor. Similarly, a homotopy $H: S^k \times [0,1] \to \mathcal{X}^N$ is continuous if and only if its component homotopies $H_i = p_i \circ H$ are continuous. This establishes a one-to-one correspondence between homotopy classes of maps into the product space and the product of the sets of homotopy classes of maps into each factor: $[S^k, \mathcal{X}^N] \cong \prod_{i=1}^N [S^k, \mathcal{X}]$. The group structure is defined component-wise, yielding the isomorphism of homotopy groups. $\square$
695: 
696: **Physical Interpretation**: The configuration space $\mathcal{X}^N$ itself remains a **fixed topological space** throughout the algorithm's execution, with homotopy groups $\pi_k(\mathcal{X}^N) \cong \pi_k(\mathcal{X})^N$ as stated above. The **dynamics** of the Fragile Gas, however, do not explore this full space uniformly. When a cloning event occurs (setting $x_j \leftarrow x_i$), the swarm **state** is instantaneously mapped to the **diagonal submanifold** $\Delta_{ij} := \{w \in \mathcal{X}^N \mid w_i = w_j\}$, which is homeomorphic to $\mathcal{X}^{N-1}$. Crucially, this is a statement about where the state **is** at that instant, not a change to the ambient space itself. The subsequent dynamics (kinetic operator, fitness forces) evolve within $\mathcal{X}^N$, potentially moving off the diagonal. Thus, cloning and selection constrain the **accessible regions** of the configuration space along lower-dimensional submanifolds, but the topology of the **space** $\mathcal{X}^N$ and its homotopy groups remain invariant. The algorithm's trajectory traces a path through various such submanifolds embedded in the unchanging topological structure of $\mathcal{X}^N$.

hints.label: rem-accessible-state-space
hints.title: Accessible State Space Topology
hints.content:
702: :label: rem-accessible-state-space
703: 
704: The **accessible state space** $\mathcal{A} \subset \mathcal{X}^N$ is the subset of configuration space that the Fragile Gas algorithm can actually reach through its dynamics (kinetic operator + cloning + selection). This is a strict subset of the full product space $\mathcal{X}^N$ due to:
705: 
706: 1. **Cloning constraints**: After cloning events, the state lies on diagonal submanifolds $\Delta_{ij} = \{w \in \mathcal{X}^N \mid w_i = w_j\}$
707: 2. **Finite-time reachability**: Only states within a bounded distance (in the algorithmic metric) from the initial condition are accessible
708: 3. **Selection barriers**: Low-fitness regions may be inaccessible due to cloning thresholds
709: 
710: The accessible space $\mathcal{A}$ is **conjectured to have a stratified structure** that can be decomposed into manifolds of varying dimensions, though this has not been rigorously proven within the framework. Its topology is far more complex than $\mathcal{X}^N$ and depends on:
711: - The cloning history (which walkers have been cloned)
712: - The fitness landscape structure (which regions are accessible)
713: - The algorithmic parameters (temperature, cloning threshold, etc.)
714: 
715: **Open Problem**: Characterize the homotopy groups $\pi_k(\mathcal{A})$ of the accessible state space. These may differ significantly from $\pi_k(\mathcal{X}^N)$ and provide deeper insight into the algorithm's exploration capabilities.
716: 
717: **Practical Implication**: While the ambient space $\mathcal{X}^N$ has trivial higher homotopy (if $\mathcal{X}$ is contractible), the accessible space $\mathcal{A}$ may have non-trivial topology due to fitness barriers creating "holes" in the reachable region. This topological obstruction can prevent the algorithm from reaching global optima.
718: 
719: **Future Work**: A rigorous analysis of $\mathcal{A}$'s topology would require:
720: - Formal definition of the accessible set as the forward-reachable set from initial conditions
721: - **Proof** that $\mathcal{A}$ admits a stratified manifold decomposition (currently conjectured but unproven)
722: - Tools from stratified space topology to characterize the stratum structure

hints.label: rem-homotopy-vs-homology
hints.title: When Homotopy Matters More Than Homology
hints.content:
728: :label: rem-homotopy-vs-homology
729: 
730: **Homology is easier to compute** (linear algebra) but **loses information**:
731: - Homology: Abelian groups, counts holes
732: - Homotopy: Potentially non-abelian groups, tracks loop structure
733: 
734: **Example**: The **Klein bottle** $K$ has:
735: - $H_1(K) \cong \mathbb{Z} \oplus \mathbb{Z}_2$ (first homology)
736: - $\pi_1(K) \cong \langle a, b \mid aba^{-1}b = 1 \rangle$ (non-abelian presentation)
737: 
738: The homotopy group reveals the **twist** in the Klein bottle that homology cannot detect.
739: 
740: **For Fragile framework**: Homology is typically sufficient for practical computations. Homotopy groups become relevant for:
741: - Detecting non-trivial loop structures in high-dimensional state spaces
